title: Soft Tissue Sarcoma
diagnosis_topic: Deep-seated enlarging mass suggestive of malignant sarcoma
setup_script: A 45-year-old man notices a progressively enlarging, painless mass in his left thigh over 6 months. He denies trauma. The mass is now causing discomfort when he walks.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 122/78 mmHg, HR 80 bpm, RR 14/min, Temp 36.7 C.
Firm, 8 cm diameter, deep to muscle, minimally mobile and nontender.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about growth and associated symptoms
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient reports gradual enlargement without weight loss or systemic symptoms.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders MRI of the thigh
dynamic_flow.reply: Reveals a heterogeneous mass within the vastus lateralis with areas of necrosis; unclear margins.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident arranges core needle biopsy

dynamic_flow.reply: CT chest/abdomen shows no metastases; baseline labs normal.
Wide local excision with 2 cm margins plus adjuvant radiotherapy vs. preoperative radiation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident inappropriately performs excisional biopsy in clinic
dynamic_flow.reply: Disrupts tissue planes and complicates definitive surgery.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident considers referral to multidisciplinary sarcoma team
dynamic_flow.reply: Oncologists, radiation oncologists and reconstructive surgeons consulted.
Regular MRI and chest imaging every 3-6 months for first 3 years.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for genetic syndromes (e.g., Li-Fraumeni)
dynamic_flow.reply: Relevant if early onset or family history of sarcoma.
Consider rotational flap or grafting depending on defect size.

critical_decision_points: Appropriate imaging and biopsy of suspected soft tissue sarcoma
Avoiding unplanned excisional biopsy that compromises margins
Multidisciplinary planning for wide local excision and adjuvant therapy
Postoperative surveillance for recurrence and metastasis
